sp.p: And, Sir, since your pity hath thus made my joys put off my fears that I should have fell forgotten, and return'd to my Mother Earth like her common Issueâ€” Thus in thankfulness with eyes to Heaven bent, and a soul full of gratitude, I vow a constant faith to virtue, andâ€”

div.stage: Enter Melintus, pursuing a Souldier, who cries help; Melintus kills and disarms him.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: To what strange fate am I reserv'd, or by what sin have I pull'd down this Curse of a general hate that all paths I tread are arm'd against me? Ha! more Enemies? Nay then, Melintus, yield, for 'tis visible thou warr'st with Heaven.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: What art thou that with such pains hast to this place hunted thy ruine, and thus with injurious wounds in the dead of night awak'd our anger?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Prithee go forward with thy injury; such another Charm will call back my anger, and then I shall be safe; for it hath ever yet been prosperous, though that success made me unfortunate.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Leave thus vaingloriously to urge your former success, for 'twill be no ground now to build a future conquest on; and therefore yield thy Sword, and quickly, before I command it and thy head; Know my power here rules even thy fate.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Yield my Sword? By what other priviledge do I hold my life among my Enemies? Prithee look upon me, and if thou canst read these Characters, they'l tell thee I was not born to yield; and though Mel. shews his wounds. thou art the glorious Master of the sport, and I unfortunate by a cross fate am hunted into the Toil where dangers on all sides begirt my innocence, yet with the Lion I dare be angry with my bonds; and although I may become thy Prey yet I will not be thy scorn.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I'll dispute no longer; Seize him; if he resist, in his heart seal the first stroke of thy freedom.

div.stage: Phil. goes towards him, and knows him.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Ha! Melintus!

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: He nam'd me; What art thou that call'st me by my name? Ye Gods, is misery so near akin that by instinct the wretched know me?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: How now! 'what do you muze on? Had you daring onely while you were unarm'd?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: No, 'twas a consideration of the baseness of the act, not fear, made me stop, and the remembrance that I am free held me from staining that maiden liberty the Gods have sent me with so base an act as to strike where there's three to one: besides, his posture and his habit speak him a Gentleman, and his misfortunes rather to be pitied than increas'd.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: A help from Heaven if this be real.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p:
Slave, and ungrateful, thou shalt finde thou hast too soon mention'd thy freedom; Fool, onely free in hope; and this act hath but increas'd thy load of chains. Curse thy self for thy increase
of miseries shall make thee finde th'art more a slave then ever.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Do not deceive thy self; look there and here.â€” And Points to chains, and shews his Dagger .ere thou art lost in thine anger, hear this truth I speak, he that is master of this and will become a slave must be a coward too; and now I'me arm'd I scorn to ow my freedom to any but the gods.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Death, dog do'st thou brave me with my courtesie? draw, They both draw and run at! Philemon .Tullius, my thirsty rage will be quench'd with nothing but the slaves blood.

sp.speaker: Melin.
sp.p: Heaven! for ought I know we are by thy direction thus cast two to two; if not, I'me sure by honour we areâ€” here, take this sword.

div.stage: [He runs in between'em, and gives Philemon the Souldiers sword.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Now, Tullius, thou shalt see how mortal thy power is, which so like a god thou wear'st among thy slaves. Revenge and freedom guide me to thy ruine; and you, Sir, strike to prevent the use of such an opportunity; a vow forbids me to tell you who I amâ€” Now the wound that thou basely gav'st me when I was bound Speaks to Tullius .and naked shall be reveng'd.

sp.speaker: Tull.
sp.p: I have but few words.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I am your choice then.

sp.speaker: Melin.
sp.p: As it happens. They fight, Tullius falls. Philemon leaves him, and runs to Melintus and parts'em.

sp.speaker: Tull.
sp.p: I am slain, and by my Slave bound for ever.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Nay, then I'll smiling fall now I have my revenge; for I see thou wert born to be a slave, and all thy acts of honour were but distempers in thee; and now thy nature is strong thou appear'st thy self a slave in thy soul; come, what stays thee, I have a breast so clear it defies thy Ponyard, Traytor.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: No, I was born free, and Manlius's rage once over he will say he has injur'd me:â€” And, Sir, as I drew my sword against my Master when Honour bad me; so when you shall seek To Melintus .to make me faulty, I am your enemy; and therefore attempt no farther this mans danger, 'tis not safe.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: My wonder waits upon all this fellows acts.

sp.speaker: Melin.
sp.p: What art thou that thus in less then a man hides more then a god?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: What am I? a soul with her old clothes on, a slave with wounds and crosses torn; and yet in better fortune I have known your face.

sp.speaker: Melin.
sp.p: If thou hast mercy in thee tell me who thou art.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Mark me well, dost thou not see thy self here? not yet?â€” Now I am sure thou do'st in these Crystal drops; friendship will guide Melintus to know Philemon. He weeps.

sp.speaker: Melin.
sp.p: Philemon! Oh ye gods! new weights to sink me!

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Oh! 'tis a powerful rod that Melintus friendship strikes with; a thousand miseries have smote upon this rock; but never any that made water issue through till now.

sp.speaker: Melin.
sp.p: Oh Philemon, Philemon, what cannot friendship do? 'tis from her living springs this dew falls.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p:
Melintus and Philemon! good heaven, what change hath
begot this misery? Oh noble Princes, upon my knees I beg, when Manlius kneels to Melintus and Philemon .your surprized joys are over, you'll shower a pardon upon unfortunate Manlius.

sp.speaker: Melin.
sp.p: Manlius! is this Manlius? he was Claricilla's friend.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: 'Tis Manlius, and I hope a fair day will break from this bloody evening.

sp.speaker: Melin.
sp.p: Your pardon, Sir, or here upon my breast return the wounds my rage directed against yours.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Repeat it not, Sir; you make me but call to mind my shame, which I must ever blushing wear when I remember a slave could look further into honour then my self.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Oh Melintus, I have a story for thee, that we shall weep out together.

sp.speaker: Melin.
sp.p: When I look upon thee, I am distracted to think the gods would consent thus to let their temples be ruin'd, and vertue always walk naked like truth's Emblem, while better fates clothe the wicked.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Dear Melintus, let not the sense of my misfortunes urge a consideration from thee at the rate of sin, nor dare those powers which I know thou fearest.

sp.speaker: Melin.
sp.p: I have done, noble youth; yet when I look upon thee, joy and amazement will seize me, I have strange things to tell thee, but this nor time nor place.â€” Who is this that thus unfortunately met thy anger?

div.stage: [Turns to Tullius that lies wounded by.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: A stout and grateful fellow; 'twas the Captain that sav'd me when I was doom'd to death by the Usurper, Silvander, 'cause I design'd Claricilla's freedom.

sp.speaker: Melin.
sp.p: He stirs; heaven, I hope, will not let the guilt of one accidental fault hang upon this evening to cross our joys.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I am sorry, since there dwelt such honour in him, that he prov'd my enemy; this was the Pirate took me at Rhodes, in that unfortunate fight where we were parted.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Pray help him aboard my Galley, where we may all repose until to morrow; and resolve what is to be done in this new change in Sicily.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Lay thy hands here, Melintus, for these bonds can only set Philemon free.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: I Have done; passion can be a friend to none, she's so unconstant; give her way, and she destroys her self; if I had been so fortunate to have spoke with you last night, I had prevented this sad chance; for I knew Melintus's anger would take a dangerous leap, when by amazement he had contracted it.

sp.speaker: Appius.
sp.p:
If I could have fear'd such a danger, I should not have been so absent with the remedy; but I am not satisfi'd how it was
discover'd by the King; yet if civility had not prevented me ere now I had spoke my fears; and long since said, beware of Olinda.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Olinda! she betray me! it cannot be, 'tis such a common fate I blush to think it; I cannot fear a punishment that comes such a road way; and yet I'll observe her: but pray what said Timillus, was Melintus wounded?

sp.speaker: Appius.
sp.p: Not dangerous, some sleight hurts he had, and upon our approach he took covert in the Wood; Timillus says he is resolv'd in some disguise to attempt to speak with you; and my counsel is to send some one that's trusty in search of him.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: I shall; and then if you please we'll walk into the Garden.

sp.speaker: Appius.
sp.p: I'll wait upon you.

div.head: ACT. V. SCEN. II.
div.stage: Enter Melintus, Philemon, Manlius, Ravack, all, but Manlius, in Slaves habits.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I Rejoyce that this day has prov'd so fortunate as to bring your youth a freedom with less sadness, then last nights storm threatned.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: Sir, my safety is a debt I owe your watchful mercy, that thus amongst the earliest of your joys could let your noble pity hunt for so lost a thing as Ravack.

sp.speaker: Melin.
sp.p: Now we are arrived we have no spare time to clothe truth fine, therefore give my naked faith a hearing; I am confident you will not refuse to take our fortunes in this design, whose innocency, though we are thus forc'd to hide with the marks of guilt, and slaves habits, yet know there is so much justice on our side, that though we fall in the attempt, and this haste prove but running to embrace the stake, yet we shall in our stories be distinguished, and live in the glorious shine which breaks from the Brows of Honours Martyrs.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: I am but one, and I'll not say I shall be fortunate; but I am certain I shall attempt any thing that may speak my gratitude.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Give me leave to break this discourse; and since you are pleas'd to trust me with this service let me not lose time; but while this expectation is in the Court let me see whether I can walk unseen, or no; and because Seleucus danger was only loss of blood, they will be more intent about him then if he had fallen; I'll be gone, the day grows old, in the Garden you say 'tis likely I shall find her, and the Prince is a young man, fair hair'd.

sp.speaker: Melin.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I am instructed.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: 'Tis the mind I see that binds or sets us free; for that being satisfi'd we have made our fears our sports, and thus mask in our miseries; but, by my life, the earnest they once were in makes me start to think thee thus miserable in jest.

sp.speaker: Melin.
sp.p:
Philemon's love is more fortunate then Melintus; for it
finds kind ways to express it self, while I unfortunate only wish and cry how fain I would rejoyce in the lasting knot, which we have thus triply tied: By blood, by love, by miseries alli'd.

div.head: ACT. V. SCEN. III.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: THis place returns my forgotten miseries, by calling to mind how happy once I was; but who are these?

sp.speaker: Appius.
sp.p: Who's that that walks there?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: I know not, is he not of your acquaintance?

sp.speaker: Appius.
sp.p: No, Madam; walk on, and mind him not.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Who would the man speak with all?

sp.speaker: Appius.
sp.p: What would you, friend? would you speak with the Princess?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Yes, Sir; Madam, I am one that wants, but cannot beg; yet when I have put off my blushes, be pleas'd to cast your eye upon a Souldiers scars, and pity a Gentleman bow'd by misfortunes, not faults, to this wretched lowness; if then your bounty find not a charity, your pardon, and I am gone.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: A Souldier is the god I worship, and to him I offer this charity.â€” Here take all that at this time I have about me; pray, Gives him a purse .of what Country are you?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: The name of Souldier is such a common Theam to beg with, and a disguise so many cheat under, that I should not dare ask like my self, but that I can shew under the honour'd hands of those Commanders where I serv'd, who and what I am; and had it been my fortune to have met the brave Princess, Melintus, and Philemon here, the service I once did them they would not have seen unrewarded.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Prithee softly; dost thou know Melintus and Philemon? say, and be not amaz'd I ask thus hastily; where did'st thou know them? gentle Souldier, speak.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, I do know 'em; and here under their hands I have to shew the service I did them, which if you please you may read.

div.stage: [He delivers her Melintus's Letter, she reades aside.

sp.speaker: Appius.
sp.p: Prithee has't of late heard of Philemen, or can'st thou tell whether he be alive or no; or can'st thou give any account of Melintus lately?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p:
Oh yes, yes, he can; read there and satisfie your self. Oh noble Manlius, where is Melintus, where is the Galley, where is Philemon? why do I stay, cannot you guide me, will not you guide me, will not Prince Appius go? I am resolv'd I will, and be miserable no longer here, where Religion, Friendship, Duty, Love no harvest bring; all my endeavours here as vainly beat the air, as the Impostors beads that fall without a Prayer; say, shall we go? will you remove me from this place so full of danger, to my friends? look, he writes to me to come, and shall I stay? no, no, Melintus, I obey; and were it to shrink into the earth I'll meet
thee, and no longer with my prayers protect this ingrateful place from the punishment her treacheries call down. Let fools like Beads-men to the Altar bow for others sins; I'll pay none but mine own vows.

sp.speaker: Appius.
sp.p: We must follow her, Sir, and within counsel or charm her passion.

sp.speaker: Seleu.
sp.p: IS there no hope of Carillus life?

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.p: No, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Seleu.
sp.p: Will Timillus scape?

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, his wounds were sleight.

sp.speaker: Seleu.
sp.p: But he shall not, nor shall fortune have power to add another sickly week to his hated days, wait all without.â€” My hopes are blasted, nor must I expect ever to gain my ends by fair means from Claricilla, I have woond up her hatred to so great height; and 'twere folly to hope a peace from a woman crost in her love; no, no, policy or force must gain the pleasure I am at.â€” Who's He knocks .there?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, the King.

sp.speaker: Seleu.
sp.p: Oh Sir, hide me from my shame, or my blushes will not let me look upon you; the disgrace brands me with coward for ever, that I should be o'recome when nothing but a Traytor struck; a thing which ought to have been the scorn, not fear of honest men when they are arm'd.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Quiet thy self, and be not troubled at such a scorn'd subject; I come to tell thee ere this shame be over, while I can with justice frown, I would have Claricilla married; and how to work our ends we'll now resolve.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, there's a Sea-man without desires to speak with you; he says he has earnest business that concerns the State.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Admit him.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Dissimulation, thou that so oft hast been prosperous in thy attempts upon the innocent, once let vertue owe thee for a service.

sp.speaker: Seleu.
sp.p: What's your business, Sir, that so hastily requires a hearing?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Ha! the King! I must not know him; Sir, be pleas'd to command your servants off, and I shall whisper a service shall claim a reward, which I will not require till it be perfect.

sp.speaker: Seleu.
sp.p: There needs no whisper here; for if it concern the Kingdom speak it to the King.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: The King! thus low I beg your pardon, Sir; and then give me leave to ask whether it be worth your care, or no, to have He kneels .in your power the stranger that fought with my Lord Seleucus.

sp.speaker: Seleu.
sp.p: softly.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
Dost thou know where he is? canst thou direct my anger
which way to seize the Traytor? if thou can'st propose thine own reward, and take a Kings word, thou shalt have my power to effect it.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Sir, I will not bargain; but in snort, thus; I have been faulty; and a Pirat speaks the kind; but 'twas while the fault was in fashion here, and a thief (Silvander) wore the Crown; your pardon for my past faults is the reward I beg for this service; which if I were not confident I could do I were mad thus to wake your anger with a deluded hope. But to the business; early this morning there came to my Galley (which now rides in the haven) two strangers, as they pretended, that had unfortunately in a duel slain one that had a neer relation to your Majesty, and by many arguments pleaded my protection; which at first sight their miseries engag'd me to, and I undertook to serve them: one of them (the fair-hair'd-man) gave me a Letter to deliver to the Princess, from whom he says I should have great rewards if I would be faithful; I undertook it; and if this may procure my peace, when you please to command me, they are dead.

sp.speaker: Seleu.
sp.p: The Letter, prithee let's see the Letter; 'tis he for certain, but who the second should be!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: I cannot guess.

sp.speaker: Seleu.
sp.p: Thy pardon, and a reward for thy faith, upon my life, thou shalt receive.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Hast thou the Letter?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Ha! Melintus and Philemon, their hands subscribed to this treason; see Seleucus, 'tis Melintus and Philemon that in disguise have waited our destruction; the gods are just still, and now from the height of all their impious darings have let them fall into our punishments; look, they urge Claricilla to an escape by the assistance of this honest Souldier; they assure her she may safely make it, and call all this treason flying from slaughter; assist me, Seleucus, that I may invent some strange torture to afflict their falshoods.

sp.speaker: Seleu.
sp.p: Is this possible?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Work on, Mischief, till their rage has blinded them; that in the dark I may the easier lead them to their ruine. Aside.

sp.speaker: Seleu.
sp.p: Melintus and Philemon, 'tis no new danger, this; my rage distracts me; and in the strength that anger lends me I can perform all you can require from a sound and healthy friend; but do it quickly, Sir, before I am unbent; and thus by her assistance reach their ruine.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: It cannot be she should consent to my destruction.

sp.speaker: Seleu.
sp.p:
It cannot be! then he were a fool, and only sow'd dangers, to reap dangers; think you he would lose his heaven to place another there? no, 'tis visible, he loves; and that has been the cause mov'd all his darings; and that he loves the Princess, do's that start you? call to mind the surprize in the garden, what rage will that meeting fill your breast with, when you shall know 'tis no aiery, hopless, single Love; no Cupid with one Wing that
threatens now as when Silvander struck, these have made the imperfect Boy a perfect god betwixt 'em; and with return of eternal faith have given both wings and eyes, and direct by their bold souls; what to do is now upon the wing, and flies with more certain danger in your Court then death, or fire.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: This is a dangerous truth; and if my Daughter consent to their desires, they dye.

sp.speaker: Seleu.
sp.p: To be secur'd of which, seal this Letter, and deliver it this honest man; and let him deliver it to your Daughter, and urge her answer, which when he has, let him return with it to your Majesty; this will guide your justice which way to steer; and your anger shall only find the guilty; and the act being just, consequently 'tis safe; for the guilty have no revenge to follow their fall.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: I am resolv'd, if she consent they fall; dispatch him with the Letter, and let me have an answer at my Chamber.

sp.speaker: Seleu.
sp.p: Sir, now you consent to be safe, be not troubled, but leave the rest to me.â€” Now to our business, I'll immediately Exit King .send a servant for a woman of the Princess, my creature, from whom I have daily intelligence; she shall get you an opportunity to deliver the Letter; her name's Olinda; and to her I'll address you; to be false now is to be faithful.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: And that makes me so false; but stay, Sir; I have a mind to make you indebted to me for a greater benefit then you dream on.

sp.speaker: Seleu.
sp.p: Whither tend'st thou?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: To assure you I intend to be faithful, and to oblige my self; to make which good I'll put my life into your hands; and if you dare obey my directions, I'll propose away that with safety you may reach your revenge; a Crown, and Claricilla.

sp.speaker: Seleu.
sp.p: Claricilla! can'st thou propose a way to gain her? let but that appear, through fire and water, oppos'd dangers, greater then cowards fears create I'll fly to embrace it.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Within I'll instruct you, and then I'll obey the Kings directions for the Letter; which will be one step to advance our plot, and if it thrive, what I shall be I'll leave to your own bosom to resolve.

sp.speaker: Seleu.
sp.p: What thou shalt be? why, thou shalt be my bosom.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: I Wonder he stays so long; I am afraid his reason will not prevail with my Father and Seleucus; and though I was by strength of your argument perswaded to it, yet I am sorry I consented to let them know 'tis Melintus whom they pursue, a name already subject to their hate: but heaven I hope will direct all.

sp.speaker: Appius.
sp.p:
If I were not assur'd that Manlius were honest, I should not have ventur'd thus to perswade you to discover where your
health lyes; but when I am secure that those in whose power he is will with their lives protect him; and his discovery is only a bait to draw his enemy into his power; I must again desire you will with patience attend the issue of what is well design'd, however it may meet a cross.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Oh Madam, I am laden with joy; and the strangeness of the burthen makes me thus sink in the way; I have discover'd who 'tis that betrays you, 'tis Olinda; Seleucus made it his boast; but you must not yet take notice of it, but seem to relye upon her faith as a means of your escape, which is consented to by all, under a hope that they shall seize you and your friends together; I cannot tell you all the particulars now; only thus much, our designs have taken as I could wish; this Letter by their consent is return'd to you; had you seen the care your Father took that the violence the seal met might not be perceiv'd, you would have laugh'd; they expect your answer, and I have promis'd to bring it immediately, which must be, that you will meet Melintus this evening without delay, your woman only in company; and to be receiv'd from the Garden-wall; this being dispatch'd I'll to the King and shew it him, and there make all sure; Sir, you must be pleas'd to mingle your self in the presence; and there cheerfully accept any Proposition the King shall make, which shall only be what we resolve on within; and then I'll to my boat, and there in smiles pitch the bloody toyls, wherein we'll take these hunters, and make them our prey.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Lose no time, for heaven's sake, 'tis a strange torture; do not you, nor you, feel it? thus to be delaid in the path that leads to brave Melintus.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Madam, we'll lose no time; be you ready to obey yours, and I'll strictly observe my part; and I hope the next thing we discourse of will be the sacrifice due to heaven, for our deliverance.

sp.speaker: Melin.
sp.p: 'TIs about the time that Manlius bid us expect his return; if we be so happy as to see Claricilla, what kind of habit will thy joy wear? I am afraid mine will be cloth'd in a paleness, for I cannot promise my self strength enough to bear such unexpected happiness.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Prithee think not of it, let it steal upon us; I find I have not man enough to meet her without trembling; the very thought has struck a coldness through my blood; and now you have told her that I love, I could easier dye for her then speak to her; for though my love has none, yet I shall still have a guilt about me when I but look or speak to her.

sp.speaker: Melin.
sp.p: Dear Philemon, we believ'd thee lost when I told the story; and I did it that thy friendship might live in her noble mention.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Sir, your pardon for that we entertain ourselves when you stand by, to whom me-thinks Love should not be a stranger.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: I have a story too, but this no time to tell it.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Noble Princes, do 'you not finde me strangely alter'd with the joy that now possesses me? the Princess is well, and salutes you both, and the Prince kisses your hand.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Prithee let us partake the joy; Will the virtuous Claricilla come? Say, Have we an interest in this joy too?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Yes, but I have a thousand things to tell you, which if you will attend and follow my directions, we shall ere to morrow Sun see all our wishes crown'd; but let us in, for we lose time, the day will be too short to bound our business in; and onely thus much know, we but the metall bring, the Gods will have the way, and form to our deliverance the work of their own hands.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Let us softly follow, and give thanks with hearts that upwards look; for gratitude is to mercy both the Bait and Hook.

sp.speaker: Seleuc.
sp.p: THis Souldier was sent from Heaven I think to take care of me, all things run so even that he takes in hand; the Princess hath consented, the King I have perswaded to go in person and surprize her, the Prince too will bear them company, and what then?â€” My joys want a name; Melintus, Philemon, and the King, must dy, Their fate which is, I have said it. The Prince shall live, but first I will shew him Death to engage him in my action, upon no other condition shall he wear his head. O the several habits their humours will be in that Rage, Envy, Fear, and Amazement will breed in their wretched thoughts, when they shall finde my words pronounce their doom, possess me of Claricilla, whose beauties increas'd by the sweetness of force will make me more a King than all the power that a Crown can give. But I lose time, and neglect my part in my own affairs; the King and Prince I must see meet at the place, where they must stand but as Witnesses to the receipt of all my part in Heaven, a Crown and Claricilla.

div.head: ACT. V. SCEN. VIII.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p:
THis is the place he appointed we should wait for him, and 'tis much about the time he bid us expect him; if they come we shall profess a joy we hop'd not; he brings revenge along, whose fruits the Gods have been pleas'd to feast with, and
the sweets we see makes them from us Mortals with fiery injunction still inclose the Tree.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Hark, I hope he comes, the Moon is friendly, 'tis he.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Are you ready?

sp.speaker: Omnes,
sp.p: Yes, yes.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Be resolute then, and still, for th'are coming.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Are we right?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Where's the Souldier?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: He's stepp'd before.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Sir, I refrain'd to tell you what the occasion was till now, because I was asham'd to let you know my Daughters fault till you might be a witness of it, and then you would not wonder at my displeasure, when you perceive she could so put off her honour as to leave me lost in my promise to your self, and hope of a wish'd Heir to succeed me here.

sp.speaker: Appius.
sp.p: Sir, I hope some mistake has begot this doubt; the Princess ever promis'd a fair return of love to your Majesty, and I shall be glad to finde you are deceiv'd.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: No, Sir, 'tis too true; for had not Seleucus his faith been watchful this night she had made her base flight into the loath'd embraces of a Traitor and a Subject, nor does she yet know she shall be prevented.

sp.speaker: Appius.
sp.p: I am sorry, Sir, your doubts have so much reason to build upon.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: We are call'd.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: This way, your hand.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Manlius, do they know how to distinguish me?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Yes, I have given them a Sign.

div.stage: [He leads the King and Seleucus, and delivers 'em to the Slaves.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Is it long to the time she appointed?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: No, Sir, 'tis the hour she commanded me to wait; one of you look out, and if you spy a fire call, that we may approach to the Garden-wall with the Boat.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I go.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: If it be possible let Olinda fall by the board, I'de have her dead, she'll be talking else.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I have made a Light from the Princesses Window.

sp.speaker: Manl.
sp.p: Quickly then set to the Wall; and do you hear Rhodian?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Leave that to me.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Dost think they'll come? Dost thou believe I shall be happy? My Love was ever of her bliss afraid.

sp.speaker: Olind.
sp.p: You need not fear, I am confident your thoughts will be prosp'rous, I hear the water dash. Who's there, the Souldier?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Yes, 'tis I. Who's there, Olinda?

sp.speaker: Olind.
sp.p: Yes, and the Princess.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Come to the next corner, we are all ready, be speedy.

div.stage: Enter King, Appius, and Seleucus; to them Manlius, and Claricilla.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: You are safe, the Slaves are the men I told you of; your Father, Appius, and Seleucus are all here; but be confident.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Stand close till they be off the Wall, and Olinda come, for she is guilty too.

div.stage: Enter Manlius, Melintus, Philemon, and Ravack.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Fall'n by the board, and not to be found? S'death, Slave, thy life shall answer the neglect.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: She perish'd by her haste, no fault of mine.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Leave your prating, Sirrah. Madam, your pardon for this unfortunate accident, your Maid is lost, fall'n by chance by the board, and drown'd; I should not dare to look you in the face after this but that I am confident I shall shew you other Friends that are as dear to you.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: My Maid lost! O set me back again, this ill omen foretells a greater danger.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Can there be danger to Claricilla where these Friends are?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Ha! Traitor to my Love and me, What hast thou done?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Thou art a Traitor, unworthy, no more a Daughter, but the sin and shame of my blould; Fool that thou art, couldst thou thou believe that thy base passion could walk id so close a disguise that my anger could not finde it: no, thou art deceiv'd; and to urge thee to despair, know, thy obscure Paramours, Melintus and Philemon, (the two Wolves to my heart) thou hast thus with safety cut away, put off to the shoar, and there thou shalt behold their ruine.

div.stage: Manlius stands by the King, Philemon goes to Claricilla, Ravack to Appius, they seize them.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Yes, Put off, that's the Word, and then put off hope, and in amazement behold the Lightning that's wrap'd in this swoln cloud, which now breaks, and in death shoots your several fates.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Heaven, thou art just; and 'tis equal to let me fall in the design I laid to destroy those noble youths; but for thee, I will not look upon such an hated Traitor when I am so near my home.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: No, you must be witness first to the Marriage of this Princess, then you shall both be a Sacrifice to our Hymen.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Thy wife? I smile upon thee; thou art so base a thing thou couldst never finde my anger yet; my scorn was ever strong enough to strangle thy hopes.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Anon 'twill be my time to smile when dy'd in thy Father's bloud, my Revenge shall force all their Sweets from thee which I will gather in the presence of thy Paramour; nor shall he or these have liberty to dy before I have enjoy'd thee; but that act once past the Earth shall not redeem their Lives; Do you perceive how small a share you are like to have in this Kingdom?

sp.speaker: Appius.
sp.p: I am glad to see thee grown to such a height of sin; for now my hopes tell me the Gods will not suffer such a Dog to bay them long, their Lightning will shoot thee, Monster.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Sir, stay not to talk, but away to Neptune's. Temple; when we have perform'd what you resolv'd there, then to the Gally, and end your hunt.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Binde them then, and let's be gone.

div.head: ACT. V. SCEN. IX.
div.stage: Enter Timillus above, Jacomo below knocking.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: WHo's there?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: 'Tis I, Jacomo; we are lost if you stay this night, your Friends aboard are betray'd to the King, and the Princess that was this night to meet him is surpriz'd in her journey by the treachery of a Souldier that they trusted; and if you attempt not your escape you are lost; your Window's large and stands upon the Haven; if you can swim, this night leap in, and I'll be ready on the shoar to receive you, with dry Cloaths and Horses, to convey us to our safety; if you stay you perish.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Nay, I can swim, but the season is somewhat too cold for that pleasure; I could be glad to have the wounds the mad Dog gave me cur'd without being drench'd in Salt-water; but however if you'll assist me, I'll leap far enough.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: What hour shall I expect you?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: At Twelve.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Till then Farewell.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: There's some comfort yet, where there is a way, when leaping forth a Window can do't; Well, if I get free if ever I come into any company that think it lawful to love any woman longer than a man has use of the Sex, they shall geld me. By this hand I have lain with a hundred unsound Wenches with less danger than I have look'd upon this wooing, this scurvy honourable Matrimony, which is so dangerous a thing the very standers by are not safe. I must swim but for wishing well to it; but from this time either Melintus shall quit his honourable way to his Loves, or I'll leave him to the honourable dangers.

div.head: ACT. V. SCEN. X.
div.stage: Enter Seleucus, King, Melintus, Manlius, Ravack, Appius, Philemon, Claricilla, and a Priest.

sp.speaker: Seleuc.
sp.p: STand, now Priest do your office.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Has this impious Traitor bound the hands of Justice, that thus she lets him proceed to mischief, and will not in her own battle strike? Must the innocent fall and none defend them?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Yes, fair one, and in their usual way shew their power, which thus from the meanest of the earth Heaven has rais'd me a Guard for your Virtues.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Who is so much a Slave that he can let this sin chain him for ever?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: How's this?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: We that have together born our miseries, and with a harsh fate worn out our weary days, have not amongst them all met one that will ly so heavy on us as this base act if we assist the Traitor.

sp.speaker: Rav.
sp.p: Sir, be free, and let honour onely draw your Sword.

div.stage: Ravack releases Appius, they draw, as Seleucus attempts Manlius sets a Dagger to his breast.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Kill that Traitor, Slave.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Free the Kingâ€” Fool, canst thou yet read the miseries thy hated life shall feel? Here Melintus tells thee what they are.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Melintus!

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Yes, Melintus, whilest Philemon and Manlius triumph in the Victory their Loyalty has gain'd over thy insulting treacheriesâ€” Sir, to you I kneel for pardon, for thus venturing to threaten dangers; all else are acquainted with the Plot we laid to discover to your abused trust this wretched Monster.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: The Prince, Sir, was of Council in all we did.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: And we have his consent, Sir, to be happy.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Of all I ask a pardon whom my doubt has injur'd; and I'll no longer cross your joys, you have my consent, and Heaven crown your wishes; but for thee, thy villany shall destroy thee.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Madam, to your virtues which my mischiefs still have hunted thus low I bow, and when with repentant tears I have wash'd the way let my last breath finde your faith. That I lov'd the rate I would have paid speaks how much; and since from him I derive these miseries, by his power which you have bow'd to I beg and conjure your mercy that it may in pardon finde me; and then with a wound here I'll give Balm to those under which my honour now languishes.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Disarm him.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Attempt it not.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Hold, I forgive.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Can you forgive? O! this mercy has chang'd my opinion; I thought nothing could have made Claricilla more like an Angel: but this mercy has added to all thy beauties a heavenly form; and one wound to those that justice threatens; and thus, fair soul, 'tis fit I offer myself, though none be more unfit for sacrifice: He stabs himself .and whilest my faults expire in the bloud that bred them, from Heaven onely shall Seleucus beg a pity, my hate dwell with all the rest. O turn not, but look upon the ruine you have made; and while I thus gazing dy, witness my Heven, (which is Claricilla) I fall to love and scorn a Martyr.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: While Justice striking let me lift a hand: Here Melintus, this I hope will cure all the wounds my unkindess gave thee; and now to Court, that when thou hast these bonds put off Hymen may new Fetters bring.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Sir, your pardon, if I say I must not change this habit till my joys are full, and by another bond freed; this Disguise has been so fortunate that I dare not quit it while 'tis possible to miss my wishes.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Take your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: O Madam, you have heard a story which makes me blush to look upon you.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Philemon must not be troubled now when our joys are thus complete, but live in smiles to recount our miseries.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: The story how he came to be thus happy we'll reserve to crown our Feast with; Manlius, thy part in the success of this day shall not be forgotten. To the Boat, and then to the Temple, and let the Priests sing an Epithalamiumto these Lovers praise, whole faiths have turn'd their Chains to Myrtle and triumphant Bays.

div.stage: As they go singing off the Stage, Enter Timillus with a Rope to make his Escape, hears them sing, and thence understands 'tis all joy and peace, and so speaks.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p:
Nay, if the Winde be in that Corner I'll leap no Leaps, but thus with a Health,
The Prayers of the Laity
Give thanks for their Delivery.
